title.full: ASEAN Green Future Project Phase 2.2 Report, Analysis and Modelling of Power Sector in Thailand

publisher.full: Sustainable Development Solutions Network and ClimateWorks Centre

description: Thailand-specific pathway reflecting current energy policy and continued ambition.
expertOverview:
#### Pathway Description

The More Ambitious Policy (MAP) scenario from the ASEAN Green Future project reflects and expands on Thailand’s Existing Policy (EXT) scenario, integrating policy targets around renewable energy shares and energy efficiency improvements. The MAP scenario is based on frameworks and policy plans such as the Energy Efficiency Plan 2018–2037, the Alternative Energy Development Plan 2018–2037, and the Power Development Plan 2018–2037. All these frameworks and plans have targets until 2037, after which the MAP scenario assumes a continuation of the growth trend for both energy efficiency improvements and renewable electricity share until 2060.

The MAP is still a somewhat conservative outlook in the sense that it does not raise the ambition of Thailand’s energy transition significantly in the near term compared to existing policies. It assumes that no significant new technologies are deployed at scale and that the deployment rate of renewable electricity capacity only starts to diverge from the EXT scenario after 2037. However, by assuming continued increases in both energy efficiency and renewable energy share, MAP brings emissions back down to 2024 levels around 2050, most notably through replacing coal- and gas-fired power plants with expanding renewable energy capacity.

The ASEAN Green Future regional research project is run by the United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network, Climateworks Centre, and local researchers from leading universities. The project develops national policy analysis and near-zero pathways that are meant to provide policy recommendations and support policymakers.

#### Core Drivers

GDP growth, continuing urbanization, and technology shifts all contribute to sustained electricity demand growth over the full time frame of the pathway. 

*Policies:* The MAP scenario assumes that the Thai power sector will reach energy efficiency targets and renewable energy share targets that are in line with existing government plans, and then it extrapolates continued improvements in these parameters to 2060. Changes in power capacity, generation, and emissions are driven primarily by these policy targets until the end of the pathway’s time frame in 2060.

*Technology deployment and electrification:* Growing shares of EVs and electric trains in transport; access to efficient lighting, cooling, and cooking in residential buildings; and efficiency improvements in industry all contribute to growing electricity demand and a reduction in GHG emissions.

#### Application to Transition Assessment

The MAP scenario is an exploratory pathway for energy transition analysis that follows many of the assumptions from the EXT scenario from the same developers, and extends those assumptions from 2037 until 2060. Effectively this scenario explores a case where existing policy objectives are met and followed up with updated targets in the future.

With its focus on existing policies and their extension into future decades, the MAP pathway is well-suited to assessing the alignment of corporate targets, plans, and investment pipelines against government policies. Misalignment to the MAP scenario indicates that a company or plan may already be falling behind forecast rates of change. This could signal exposure to regulatory risk or declining market share as low-carbon segments of the power sector are encouraged to grow. 

While the MAP scenario includes aspirational 2060 targets extrapolated from existing 2037 targets, it is still a relatively conservative projection of the energy transition and does not differ strongly from the EXT scenario until 2037. Therefore, company plans that exceed the rate of transition that is forecast in the MAP scenario may still be exposed to future risks if more stringent policies are implemented before 2037 or if technology shifts occur faster than modeled.

The MAP scenario does not include details about technology costs, supply chain dependencies, or investment needs, which means that it has clear limitations in assessing the commercial and technical feasibility of transition strategies.

Annual projections for power capacity, electricity generation, and emissions use a moderately detailed breakdown by energy sources such as coal, natural gas, wind, solar, and biomass. These are relevant and useful for analyzing specific decarbonization levers and project investment pipelines within company plans. Due to its country-specific nature, the MAP scenario has limited applicability to companies with diversified operations across multiple geographies, but it offers solid detail and specificity for operations in Thailand.
